title: No Data, No Worries : Fabricatr
text:
Motivation



Rarely work on my own data.
Literate, reproducible workflow

Org-Babel
RMarkdown
Quarto.

Scripts to clean, summarise, plot and analyse data.





The Turing Way project illustration by Scriberia. Used under a CC-BY 4.0 licence. DOI: 10.5281/zenodo.3332807




::: {.notes} Speaker Notes can be added to each slide. Formatting can be used here too. :: : ## Problem



Rarely is full data set available!

title: No Data, No Worries : Fabricatr
text:
Fabricatr

fabricatr - Imagine Your Data Before You Collect It



install.packages("fabricatr")
library(fabricatr)
library(visdat)
library(nanair)

set.seed(55138)


Binary variables
Categorical/factors
Continuous
Time-Series
Correlated
Intra-Class Correlation (ICC)




Speaker Notes can be added to each slide. Formatting can be used here too.

title: No Data, No Worries : Fabricatr
text:
Basic Example



100 observations.
Binary : draw_binary().
Binomial : draw_binomial().
Continuous (0-1) : runif().
Random Normal (mean = 38, sd = 16) : rnorm().



dummy_df <- fabricatr::fabricate(
    N = 100,
    binary = fabricatr::draw_binary(
        N,
        prob = runif(N)
        ),
    binomial = fabricatr::draw_binomial(
        prob = runif(N),
        trials = 2
        ),
    uniform = runif(N),
    random_normal = rnorm(N, 38, 16)
)
dummy_df |> head()

   ID binary binomial    uniform random_normal
1 001      1        2 0.44476930      53.31541
2 002      0        1 0.25068383      27.33481
3 003      1        1 0.36067220      18.89239
4 004      0        2 0.09717732      27.17577
5 005      1        0 0.43867820      27.08348
6 006      0        1 0.49283394      42.99562





R code can be embeded and executed to produce tables and figures.

title: No Data, No Worries : Fabricatr
text:
Basic Example - Summary



library(gtsummary)

gtsummary::tbl_summary(
    dummy_df,
    include = c(binary,
                binomial,
                uniform,
                random_normal))











Characteristic
N = 1001

title: No Data, No Worries : Fabricatr
text:
Categorical Variables



100 observations
Generate random normal using rnorm()
Categorise using draw_ordered() and setting breaks.
Label variables with break_labels



cat_df <- fabricatr::fabricate(
    N = 100,
    x = rnorm(N),
    ordered = fabricatr::draw_ordered(
        x,
        breaks = c(-Inf,
                   -1,
                   -0.5,
                   0,
                   0.5,
                   1,
                   Inf),
        break_labels = c("Group 1",
                         "Group 2",
                         "Group 3",
                         "Group 4",
                         "Group 5",
                         "Group 6")
    )
)




R code can be embeded and executed to produce tables and figures.

title: No Data, No Worries : Fabricatr

Categorical Variables - Summary



gtsummary::tbl_summary(
    cat_df,
    include = c(ordered)
